Situation1: Laundry piles up, but someone eventually finds time to fold it.
Expectation2: Diagnose patient illnesses accurately based on symptoms and tests
Situation2: A patient with symptoms of the common cold has come in for a routine check-up.
Story:
I stare at the mountain of laundry on the couch, shirts and socks tumbling over each other in a silent accusation. My wife’s voice echoes in my mind, gentle but tired: “Can you help fold these tonight? I’ve had a long day.” I promised I would, but now my phone buzzes with a message from the clinic—my last patient is waiting. I grab my coat, guilt gnawing at me as I leave the laundry untouched.

At the clinic, I sit across from a patient sniffling and coughing, symptoms pointing to a common cold. But I know I can’t just assume; I have to be thorough, ask the right questions, order the right tests if needed. My mind drifts back to home, to the laundry, to my wife’s weary face. I feel the weight of both worlds pressing in—one expects me to be present, to share the load; the other demands my focus, my expertise, my undivided attention. My heart pounds as I realize I can’t be in both places at once, and I’m left suspended, torn between the person I love and the duty I’ve sworn to uphold.
